Off Topic: "The Hammer" an inspirational movie.

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-28-2011 03:16 AM

I hope Angela sees this. I went and saw "The Hammer" tonight and enjoyed every minute. The star of the movie was Angela's cousin and he did a superb job. The movie was about a Deaf Man who became the first Deaf person to win the NCAA wrestling championship for 3 straight years. He was named to the NCAA Hall of Fame. It documents his life growing up and what he had to face. It shows how he was taught he could do and be anything he wanted to do and be but at the same time it showed how he not only needed to trust himself but that he needed the support of those who were Deaf like him and could understand how he felt. The film is open-captioned so that you Hearing can understand what is happening. There were some really funny moments that took place in American Sign Language and it was funny because you could tell who was Deaf and who was not because the Deaf would laugh and the Hearing just looked puzzled but it is a Deaf Humor thing. The movie itself is inspiring and teaches us to hold onto our dreams. If any of you see it is playing in your area I highly recommend seeing it if you can. It is worth every penny and every minute.

Thank you Angela for letting us know about this movie. I so enjoyed it.

a Deaf person with Diabetes.

‎10-28-2011 08:38 PM

Hi Mack,

 

That's great. I'm glad you enjoyed the movie. It kind of reminds me of the former governor of New York who now has a radio show, David Paterson. He's not deaf, but legally blind and he was also brought up by his parents and told that he could do anything that a "normal" sighted person could do. Look at what these people have achieved. There's got to be something to that way of thinking! Thanks for the review!﻿

Sharon

Type 1 since March 29, 1983 (12 years old)
Using a minimed pump since 2004

‎10-28-2011 11:25 PM

Deafmack,

 

I am SO glad you enjoyed the movie! I and the rest of the family are very proud of Theo and I thought his performance was wonderful. Of course, I am biased, but I do think that for the short time he was on screen, you really saw a strong range of emotions portrayed by him. It's a testament to his ability that he could do so well at that young an age.

 

I read your message to my mom and aunt (Theo's aunts) and we all had to laugh when we read your comment about the Deaf humor in the movie, since we are all three hearing people, though three who did grow up with Deaf family. It made me think about your other comment, that "he needed the support of those who were Deaf like him and could understand how he felt." It's true. It's why I think groups like this work and work well. Even we with diabetes need the support of others who are like us, who can understand how we feel. Thank you for reminding me of that!

 

You're most welcome, and again, I say THANK YOU! I know your praise would make Theo blush.

 

Angela
